Selection: Since my name starts with the letter ‘S’, I selected a dataset related to
disease named Multiple Sclerosis Disease. The dataset captures clinical and
demographic predictors associated with the conversion of Clinically Isolated
Syndrome (CIS) to Multiple Sclerosis (MS) in Mexican mestizo patients treated
between 2006 and 2010 at the National Institute of Neurology and Neurosurgery,
Mexico City.
Question 1: Exploratory Analysis of the CIS Dataset
Dataset Overview
• Observations: 273 patients. Row identifiers in the source file were treated as
row names to preserve patient IDs without using them in computations.
• Key variables:
– Gender (1 = male, 2 = female).
– Age (years at CIS diagnosis).
– Initial_Symptom (categorised index of first clinical presentation).
– Oligoclonal_Bands (0 = negative, 1 = positive, 2 = strongly positive /
repeated positivity).
– Neurophysiological indicators (LLSSEP, ULSSEP, VEP, BAEP).
– MRI findings across brain and spinal cord regions.
– Disability metrics (Initial_EDSS, Final_EDSS), reported for patients who
converted to MS (group = 1).
– group (1 = converted to MS, 2 = remained CIS).
• Missingness: Schooling and Initial_Symptom each have one missing value.
Initial_EDSS and Final_EDSS are unavailable for 148 patients (all in group = 2).
No other variables contain missing entries.
• Clinical context: The combination of MRI and neurophysiological measures
enables the joint analysis of inflammatory burden and electrophysiological
response, both of which are relevant to conversion risk.

1.4 Visual Exploration

Observations: -
• Age clusters between late 20s and mid-30s, with the histogram peaking around 25-
35 and tapering gradually toward older ages; very few observations below 20 or
above 60.
• Distribution skews slightly right: a tail extends into the 60-70 range, but counts fall
quickly. The stacked dot plot’s mean line lies just right of the median, confirming
mild positive skew.
• Age values are almost all integers, so the dot plot reveals “columns” of stacked
points at each whole age-no large gaps, suggesting consistent recording across ages.
• The maximum stack height is modest (fewer than 15 observations per exact age),
indicating no single age dominates the cohort.

2.1 Sampling, PMF, and CDF Visualisations
Random samples from the Binomial distribution illustrate convergence behaviour.




2.2 Sample vs Theoretical Moments
The empirical mean and variance approach theoretical values as sample size grows. Small-
sample variance can oscillate around the theoretical variance, as evidenced by the 30-draw
sample.
2.3 Poisson Approximation to the Binomial
Observations
• Binomial PMFs and CDFs align closely with theory; as n grows the mass
spreads smoothly and the CDF transitions sharpen-symmetric
about np when p = 0.6, skewed left/right for p = 0.3/0.9.
• Expanded sample size tightens empirical dispersion around the theoretical
mean and variance, mirroring the moment table, all four raw moments differ
from expectations by well under 1%, demonstrating simulation stability.
• Higher-order moment deviations increase mildly with larger n and extreme p,
consistent with sampling noise concentrated near the distribution boundaries.
• Poisson overlays show a strong approximation when p = 0.3 (classic “rare
event” regime). The gap widens for p = 0.6 and becomes pronounced at p =
0.9, illustrating the sensitivity of the approximation to large success
probabilities.
• Overall, the grid confirms that sample moments converge to theory with
larger n, and that Poisson is only a good surrogate for Binomial when p is small
while np remains moderate.
